text: In Greek mythology, Phthia (/ˈθaɪə/; Greek: Φθία or Φθίη Phthía) may refer to the following individuals: * Phthia, daughter of Phoroneus and mother of Achaeus by the god Zeus.Pseudo-Clement, Recognitions 10.21 This version is to some extent confirmed by Aelian, who relates that Zeus assumed the shape of a dove to seduce a certain Phthia.Aelian, Varia Historia 1.15 * Phthia, the beloved of Apollo, by whom she became the mother of Dorus, Laodocus, and Polypoetes.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 1.7.6 * Phthia, a Theban princess who was one of the Niobids, children of Amphion, king of Thebes and Niobe, daughter of Tantalus.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 3.5.6Hyginus, Fabulae 11 & 69 * Phthia or Clytia, concubine of Amyntor who falsely accused her stepson, Phoenix, of seduction causing his father to blind him.Pseudo-Apollodorus.
